results.title: Promoting pupil adjustment
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Planning for Teaching”.
Presents actual case studies to show how a secondary school teacher helps pupils to adjust socially. Presents in considerable detail he cases of two boys, Bill, a shy newcomer who is encouraged when interest si shown in his outside activities; and Fred, who has developed unsocial behaviour patterns. Summarizes the cases of two other boys who lack confidence.

results.title: Planning for personal and professional growth
results.creator_credit: George L. George, McGraw-Hill Films and Sturgis-Grant Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Planning for Teaching”.
Shows how teachers need to maintain their own mental growth and resilience to make the most of teaching. Dramatises cases of four typical teachers to explain how a teacher can avoid failure and frustration, and give inspiration instead of boredom to their charges. Stresses that teachers need to make conscious effort to deepen their understanding.

results.title: Guiding the growth of children
results.creator_credit: George L. George and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Planning for Teaching”.
Shows that developing the pupil as an individual is the most important part of the teacher’s job. A teacher tells how she dealt with a number of cases of “problem children”, by an individual approach in each case. These children include a poor reader, a shy girl, a bully, and clown, a stutterer and a pupil with a very hight IQ.

results.title: Effective learning in elementary school
results.creator_credit: George L. George and Sturgis-Grant Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Planning for Teaching”.
A teacher in primary school tells of some of her own experiences in making learning more effective. In her class, teacher and pupil work together on the basic skills such as reading and writing. But stronger motivation for learning is derived from unit study projects, which also give pupils opportunities to develop social skills.

results.title: Broader concepts of curriculum
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Planning for Teaching”.
Shows American ideals of a broader education in living for adolescents, under the headings of civic competence, vocational orientation, preparation for family living, and health and physical fitness. High school students are seen as they elect their own leaders, and to research into social questions such as the power of pressure groups. Also shown are the types of vocational guidance and practical experience needed. Discussions on family problems, training for leisure, sport, are other elements of a broad curriculum.

results.title: Planet earth
results.creator_credit: Gregory Andorfer, National Academy of Sciences (U.S.) and WQED
results.brief_description: An Emmy award winning series which uses the latest satellite and computer imagery to illustrate the most recent discoveries which have been made relating to influences on the Earth’s physical formation, evolution, climate and geological future.

results.title: Fate of the Earth
results.creator_credit: Robin Bates, National Academy of Sciences (U.S.) and WQED
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Planet earth”.
This program explores the role of life in shaping the Earth to become what it is today. New discoveries tell us that life maybe a billion years older than previously thought. The program illustrates new theories of a “nuclear winter” and an “ultra-violet spring”. Narrated by Richard Kiley.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robin Bates, National Academy of Sciences (U.S.) and WQED

results.title: The Solar sea
results.creator_credit: Georgann Kane, National Academy of Sciences (U.S.) and WQED
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Planet earth”.
Our sun is a star that powers the earth. it gives life, creates weather, warms the oceans, the land and even the ice. This program looks at the history of man’s involvement with the sun, and with the latest research into such phenomena as sun spots, solar flares and the solar wind, using infra-red and x-ray satellite photography to illustrate the immense forces which ultimately control the future of the earth.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Georgann Kane, National Academy of Sciences (U.S.) and WQED
